qas.question: Based on the above definition, materialism is not consistent with what?
Based on the above definition, materialism is consistent with what?
What book defined materialism as a non-philosophical system?
Christianity, Judaism, and Islam all agree with what philosophy?
What is created for a person when they perceive Brahman?
What religion does not believe in an illusion called Maya?

context: According to the <b2_0>Catholic Encyclopedia<b2_0/> of 1907-1912, materialism, defined as "a philosophical system which regards matter as the only reality in the world [...] denies the existence of God and the soul". <b3_0>Materialism<b3_0/>, in this view, therefore becomes incompatible with most world <a0_0><b1_0>religions<b1_0/><a0_0/>, including Christianity, Judaism, and Islam. In such a context one can conflate materialism with atheism. Most of <b5_0>Hinduism<b5_0/> and transcendentalism regards all matter as an illusion called Maya, blinding humans from knowing "the truth". Maya is the limited, purely physical and mental reality in which our everyday consciousness has become entangled. <b4_0>Maya<b4_0/> gets destroyed for a person when s/he perceives Brahman with transcendental knowledge.
